But, how can one remove this violation? Impossible.
We should ignore single node collections and named variables.

title: Support nameless arguments convention

milestone.title: Version 0.14 aka python3.8
milestone.description:
`python3.8` will be released on `Monday, 2019-10-21`
https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0569/#schedule

We need to support it in two month.

body:
# Bug report

Nameless arguments convention used in type annotations of callables causes WPS112

## What's wrong

Taken from [mypy documentation](https://mypy.readthedocs.io/en/latest/additional_features.html#extended-callable-types):

```python
from typing import Callable
from mypy_extensions import (Arg, DefaultArg, NamedArg,
                             DefaultNamedArg, VarArg, KwArg)

def func(__a: int,  # This convention is for nameless arguments
         b: int,
         c: int = 0,
         *args: int,
         d: int,
         e: int = 0,
         **kwargs: int) -> int:
    ...

F = Callable[[int,  # Or Arg(int)
              Arg(int, 'b'),
              DefaultArg(int, 'c'),
              VarArg(int),
              NamedArg(int, 'd'),
              DefaultNamedArg(int, 'e'),
              KwArg(int)],
             int]

f: F = func
```

The same goes for callback protocols (also taken from [mypy documentation](https://mypy.readthedocs.io/en/latest/protocols.html#callback-protocols)):

```python
from typing import Callable, TypeVar
from typing_extensions import Protocol

T = TypeVar('T')

class Copy(Protocol):
    def __call__(self, __origin: T) -> T: ...

copy_a: Callable[[T], T]
copy_b: Copy

copy_a = copy_b  # OK
copy_b = copy_a  # Also OK
```

As seen here, double-underscore variable names are used to specify nameless function arguments when annotating callables. This causes WPS112 (Found private name pattern).

## How it should be

While I agree with WPS112, I think this is a special case where it should be allowed, especially in the latter case of callback protocols, where the dunder name is only used to define the protocol.

title: Make `WPS113` respect `i_control_code` setting, again

milestone.title: Version 0.14 aka python3.8
milestone.description:
`python3.8` will be released on `Monday, 2019-10-21`
https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0569/#schedule

We need to support it in two month.

body:
I made a terribly wrong decision in #951 and asked to make WPS113 ignored when `i_control_code=True`

But this is wrong! We need to ignore WPS133 when we are developing libraries. 
Which means that `i_control_code=False`

This needs to be fixed.

Related #951 
Files to be modified: https://github.com/wemake-services/wemake-python-styleguide/commit/924fe11aee6b65eb1b06743e131d4de76689e869

title: False positive for WPS226 with string types

milestone.title: Version 0.14 aka python3.8
milestone.description:
`python3.8` will be released on `Monday, 2019-10-21`
https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0569/#schedule

We need to support it in two month.

body:
I get this error when checking `returns` source code:

```
./returns/context/requires_context_result.py
  0:1      WPS226 Found string constant over-use: RequiresContextResult[_EnvType, _NewValueType, _ErrorType]
```

It is really ugly that our linter checks string types as constants.
They should be excluded from the check.

There's nothing I can do about them.

title: WPS501 is too strict when defining context managers

milestone.title: Version 0.14 aka python3.8
milestone.description:
`python3.8` will be released on `Monday, 2019-10-21`
https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0569/#schedule

We need to support it in two month.

body:
# Bug report

<!--
Hi, thanks for submitting a bug. We appreciate that.

But, we will need some information about what's wrong to help you.
-->

## What's wrong

<!-- Describe what is not working. Please, attach a traceback. -->

Simple usage of `@contextlib.contextmanager`decorator leads to WPS501. Example:

```
    @contextlib.contextmanager
    def _context(self, amount: int):
        old_spaces = self.spaces
        self.spaces = old_spaces + amount
        try:
            yield
        finally:
            self.spaces = old_spaces
```

flake8 output for this generates the following on the line with the `try:` statement.

```
WPS501 Found `finally` in `try` block without `except`
```

There's no particular logic that would be needed in case of an error, except that cleanup must be performed.

## How is that should be

<!-- Describe how it should work. -->

The check should be relaxed in the definition of a context manager using the decorator.

<!--

  Love wemake-python-styleguide? ❤️
  Do you want your bugs to be solved faster?

  Please consider supporting our collective:
👉  https://opencollective.com/wemake-python-styleguide/donate

-->

## System information

### flake8 information

Contents of `flake8 --bug-report`:

```
{
  "dependencies": [
    {
      "dependency": "entrypoints",
      "version": "0.3"
    }
  ],
  "platform": {
    "python_implementation": "CPython",
    "python_version": "3.8.1",
    "system": "Linux"
  },

    {
      "is_local": false,
      "plugin": "flake8-annotations-complexity",
      "version": "0.0.2"
    },
    {
      "is_local": false,
      "plugin": "flake8-bandit",

title: WPS331 doesn't make sense if additional work needs to be done

milestone.title: Version 0.14 aka python3.8
milestone.description:
`python3.8` will be released on `Monday, 2019-10-21`
https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0569/#schedule

We need to support it in two month.

body:
I get a WPS331 error with code like this:

```
        try:
            vehicles = await self.client.list_vehicles()
        except tesla_api.AuthenticationError as e:
            return error

        save_api_details()
        return vehicles
```

Until the assignment is completed successfully, I don't know if the API details are correct. Therefore, they need to be saved after the assignment, but before the return.

I'd propose to avoid this rule if there are additional statements between the assignment and the return.

title: Multiple excepts raising 440/441

milestone.title: Version 0.14 aka python3.8
milestone.description:
`python3.8` will be released on `Monday, 2019-10-21`
https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0569/#schedule

We need to support it in two month.

body:
Not sure these violations seem correct to me. With code such as:

```
try:
  ...
except OneException as e:
  do_something(e)
except AnotherException as e:
  do_something_else(e)
```

This throws WPS440 and WPS441.

Not sure why this is considered a block variables overlap, when only one of these blocks will be run, and the variable is referencing the local block variable.

WPS441 also looks wrong as the variable is not used after the block as it claims, but only within the block that defined it.

title: WPS425 boolean non-keyword argument clashes with setdefault
WPS245 on single argument functions
body:
It would be a good addition to WPS245 if it was able to ignore functions which take only one argument. If you are able to inspect the actual function, then only ignore when the argument is mandatory.

In many cases these arguments are self-explanatory, for example: `set_sensitive(False)`
This looks a bit silly to me when it's rewritten as: `set_sensitive(sensitive=False)`

title: WPS332 Found implicit ternary expression on boolean expression

milestone.title: Version 0.14 aka python3.8
milestone.description:
`python3.8` will be released on `Monday, 2019-10-21`
https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0569/#schedule

We need to support it in two month.

body:
After reading https://wemake-python-stylegui.de/en/latest/pages/usage/violations/consistency.html#wemake_python_styleguide.violations.consistency.ImplicitTernaryViolation, I don't understand why the following code:
```python
if first_condition and second_condition or third_condition:
    do_stuff()
```
triggers WPS332. The closest related issue I could find is https://github.com/wemake-services/wemake-python-styleguide/issues/604. On that example, it is clear that it's a ternary expression to make an assignment. But applying that same reasoning to any boolean logic that combines `and`s and `or`s like the example from above does not seem adequate to me.

The only way I found around it is with the construct:
```python
trigger_do_stuff = third_condition if first_condition else second_condition
if trigger_do_stuff:
    do_stuff()
```
Which strikes me as confusing and not readable.

I would appreciate an explanation of how that boolean logic should be correctly expressed according to WPS, or if this case shouldn't be flagged by 332 (on that case, I would open a bug ticket).

title: False positive implicit yield violation
body:
# Bug report

<!--
Hi, thanks for submitting a bug. We appreciate that.

But, we will need some information about what's wrong to help you.
-->

## What's wrong
With common function to split iterable by chunks WPS raises `ImplicitYieldFromViolation`
<!-- Describe what is not working. Please, attach a traceback. -->
```
def chunks(value, chunk_size):
    """Yield successive n-sized chunks from l."""
    for index in range(0, len(value), chunk_size):
        yield value[index:index + chunk_size]
```

## How is that should be
`ImplicitYieldFromViolation` should be raised only if no other operations with iterable item.

title: False positive for WPS528
body:
# Bug report

<!--
Hi, thanks for submitting a bug. We appreciate that.

But, we will need some information about what's wrong to help you.
-->

## What's wrong

<!-- Describe what is not working. Please, attach a traceback. -->

False positive for `WPS528`. Because we allow to use mutation inside assignment.
And do not require to use `.items()` here. 

Code:

```python
class MyClass(DjangoForm):
    def __init__(self, *args, **kwargs) -> None:
         super().__init__(*args, **kwargs)
         for field_name in self.fields:
            if field_name not in self._not_required_fields:
                self.fields[field_name].required = True
```

Output:

```
./server/web_app/logics/forms/base.py

  22:9     WPS528 Found implicit `.items()` usage
  for field_name in self.fields:
  ^
```

title: False positive for WPS504
body:
# Bug report

<!--
Hi, thanks for submitting a bug. We appreciate that.

But, we will need some information about what's wrong to help you.
-->

## What's wrong

This code produces a false positive violation:

```python
def test():
    delta = due - since
    if not delta.days:
        raise ValidationError(FormatErrorMessages.empty_duration)
    elif delta.days > max_days:
        raise ValidationError(FormatErrorMessages.too_long_duration)
    return due
```

Output:

```
361   51:5     WPS504 Found negated condition
362   if not delta.days:
363   ^
```

## How is that should be

We don't have an `else` clause here. I cannot switch this condition.
So, when `else` is missing, we should ignore this violation.

<!-- Describe how it should work. -->

I suggest adding one complex example like the above one.

title: Forbid repeating conditions in the one condition block
body:
# Rule request

<!-- Thanks for coming up with a proposal! -->

## Thesis

In examples below, `x`, `y` and `z` are any Python expressions. For example, `x and x` can be `func(a, b, c=3) and func(a, b, c=3)`.

Bad:

```python
if x and x: ...
if x or x: ...
if x and not x: ...
if x or not x: ...
```

Good:

```
if x: ...
if not x: ...
```

If we're brave enough, we can after this rule care a little bit about conditions simplification:

```
x or x and y == x or y
x and y or y and z == y and (x or z)
```

## Reasoning

In most of cases it's a logical mistake. Every condition above can be reduced to `x`, `True` or `False`, and usually, it's not what you expect.

<!--
Why do you think this is a good idea?

Please, include some strong points and considerations.
-->

<!--

  Love wemake-python-styleguide? ❤️
  Do you want your features to be implemented faster?

  Please consider supporting our collective:
👉  https://opencollective.com/wemake-python-styleguide/donate

-->

title: MultipleContextManagerAssignmentsViolation with several managers
body:
# Bug report

<!--
Hi, thanks for submitting a bug. We appreciate that.

But, we will need some information about what's wrong to help you.
-->

## What's wrong
This rule was created to forbid `with open('') as first, second:` where it's hard to find from where was `second` variable.

But if I want to use several context managers like that
```python
with A() as a, B() as b:
    ...
```
I receive MultipleContextManagerAssignmentsViolation.
<!-- Describe what is not working. Please, attach a traceback. -->

## How is that should be
MultipleContextManagerAssignmentsViolation should not raise on multiple context managers
<!-- Describe how it should work. -->

title: Problem with BooleanPositionalArgumentViolation
body:
# Bug report

<!--
Hi, thanks for submitting a bug. We appreciate that.

But, we will need some information about what's wrong to help you.
-->

## What's wrong
Some libraries (query builder in my case) have an api like that
```python
query = Query(table)
query.set(field_name, True)
```
Which raises BooleanPositionalArgumentViolation, because there is a comma, not equal sign.
<!-- Describe what is not working. Please, attach a traceback. -->

## How is that should be
Not sure. It's definitely not the best api I've seen. But I can't remove it. And settings `noqa: 
WPS425` on every line is ugly.

title: False positive BlockAndLocalOverlapViolation with type annotation
body:
# Bug report

<!--
Hi, thanks for submitting a bug. We appreciate that.

But, we will need some information about what's wrong to help you.
-->

## What's wrong
With given code
```python
import asyncpg as apg


async def db_operation(db: apg.pool.Pool):
    """Operation with db."""
    connection: apg.Connection
    async with db.acquire() as connection:
        return await connection.fetch(
            """
            SELECT * FROM table
            """
        )
```
`BlockAndLocalOverlapViolation` raises with 
```
     7:   5 WPS440 Found block variables overlap: connection [wemake-python-styleguide]
  async with db.acquire() as connection:
  ^
```

Without line ```connection: apg.Connection``` everything is ok.
<!-- Describe what is not working. Please, attach a traceback. -->

## How is that should be
This is valid python annotation and `BlockAndLocalOverlapViolation` violation should not be raised here.

<!-- Describe how it should work. -->

<!--

title: Incorrect tests for annotations
body:
# Bug report

We don't test annotations that are defined as strings.
It should be an explicit testing strategy for python<3.8

Related #985

title: Incorrect `WPS70x` logic
body:
# Bug report

<!--
Hi, thanks for submitting a bug. We appreciate that.

But, we will need some information about what's wrong to help you.
-->

## What's wrong

It now works with strings. And give false positives a lot.

Example:

```python
some = call('`Optional[None]` found and Literal[None]')
```

Gives:

```
  1:1      WPS700 Found useless `Literal[None]` typing annotation
  some = call('`Optional[None]` found and Literal[None]')
  ^

  1:1      WPS703 Found `Optional[None]` which is just `None`
  some = call('`Optional[None]` found and Literal[None]')
```

We should rethink our methods.

Related #976

title: `WPS344` ignores `//= 0`
body:
# Bug report

<!--
Hi, thanks for submitting a bug. We appreciate that.

But, we will need some information about what's wrong to help you.
-->

## What's wrong

<!-- Describe what is not working. Please, attach a traceback. -->

This code is not marked as invalid:

```python
x //= 0
```

## How is that should be

It should raise `WPS344`. See here: https://github.com/wemake-services/wemake-python-styleguide/blob/master/wemake_python_styleguide/visitors/ast/operators.py#L100

We also need to check for `ast.FloorDiv` as well.

title: `i-control-code` cannot be disabled using flake8 command option
body:
# Bug report

## What's wrong
`i-control-code=True` by default. If I have a code which violates some rules controlled by `i-control-code` (for example, WPS113) and I want to ingnore these rules, I can't just pass `--i-control-code=false` to flake8 because it won't accept it:
> flake8 --i-control-code=no --select WPS module.py
Usage: flake8 [options] file file ...

flake8: error: --i-control-code option does not take a value

The only way to ignore the violation is to set `i-control-code = False` in flake8 configuration file (setup.cfg, for example). And it's very inconvenient sometimes (see #957).
But, if `i-control-code = False` in config file, I actually can enable it from command line just passing `--i-control-code` to flake8 arguments without value.
## How is that should be
`i-control-code` should be fully configurable from both configuration file and command line.  Command line option should have precedence.
<!--

  Love wemake-python-styleguide? ❤️
  Do you want your bugs to be solved faster?

  Please consider supporting our collective:
👉  https://opencollective.com/wemake-python-styleguide/donate

-->

title: WPS210 possible misbehavior when counting variables in list comperhensions
body:
# Bug report
Counting variables in functions with list comperhensions with two or more variables inside is wrong.

```
# -*- coding: utf-8 -*-

"""Showcase for local variables."""


def check_number_of_variables():
    """Showcase for local variables."""
    first_var = [
        first + second
        for first, second in enumerate(range(10))
    ]

    second_var = [
        first + second
        for first, second in enumerate(range(10))
    ]

    third_var = [
        first + second
        for first, second in enumerate(range(10))
    ]

    fourth_var = [
        first + second
        for first, second in enumerate(range(10))
    ]

    fifth_var = [first_var, second_var, third_var, fourth_var]

    return len(fifth_var)
```

<!--
Hi, thanks for submitting a bug. We appreciate that.

But, we will need some information about what's wrong to help you.
-->

## What's wrong

<!-- Describe what is not working. Please, attach a traceback. -->

> WPS210 Found too many local variables: 7
## How is that should be

<!-- Describe how it should work. -->

No errors from WPS210

title: Add separate test for violations controlled by `i_control_code` option
body:
Some violations are ignored when `i_control_code` options is set to `True` (like WPS113). Thus, we have to disable them in `SHOULD_BE_RAISED` list because e2e tests run with `i_control_code = True`. So these violations are actually not completely tested.
Why not to have a separate list of violations which only raise when `i_control_code = False`? And run separate test(s) with `--i_control_code=False`.

title: WPS324 false-positive with nested functions
body:
# Bug report

<!--
Hi, thanks for submitting a bug. We appreciate that.

But, we will need some information about what's wrong to help you.
-->

## What's wrong

This code produces false positive `WPS324`:

```python
def test():
    def decorator():
        return
    return decorator
```

<!-- Describe what is not working. Please, attach a traceback. -->

## How is that should be

These two returns are completely different cases. We should check `.wps_context` of the node.
See: 
- https://github.com/wemake-services/wemake-python-styleguide/blob/master/wemake_python_styleguide/visitors/ast/keywords.py#L133
- https://github.com/wemake-services/wemake-python-styleguide/blob/b43e738c4527219f03c2eec420fe2e20cfd4c8cc/wemake_python_styleguide/logic/nodes.py#L29

title: WSP318 conflict with isort I001 and E128
body:
# Bug report

<!--
Hi, thanks for submitting a bug. We appreciate that.

But, we will need some information about what's wrong to help you.
-->

## What's wrong

There is no way of formatting a multi-line import without violating either WSP318 or I001 and E128.

```python
from flask import (Blueprint, current_app, flash, g, redirect, render_template,
                   request, url_for)
```

Does not yield I001 and also not E128, but it does violate WSP318. 

Fixing it so WSP318 is not violated creates violations against I001 and E128.
```python
from flask import (Blueprint, current_app, flash, g, redirect, render_template,
    request, url_for)
```

## How is that should be

WSP318 should respect visual indent (E128) and isort order (I001).

title: False positive for `WPS413`
body:
# Bug report

<!--
Hi, thanks for submitting a bug. We appreciate that.

But, we will need some information about what's wrong to help you.
-->

## What's wrong

<!-- Describe what is not working. Please, attach a traceback. -->

This code produces incorrect results:

```python
class _Callable(object):
    # Callable[[CenterProtocol[T]], T]
    def __getattr__(self, key: str) -> Callable[[object], T1]:
        return operator.attrgetter(key)
```

Output:

```
  32:5     WPS413 Found bad magic module function: __getattr__
  def __getattr__(self, key: str) -> Callable[[object], T1]:
```

## How is that should be

<!-- Describe how it should work. -->
It should work correctly: it is not a module level ` __getattr__`, it is a class-level method.

<!--

  Love wemake-python-styleguide? ❤️
  Do you want your bugs to be solved faster?

  Please consider supporting our collective:
👉  https://opencollective.com/wemake-python-styleguide/donate

-->

I am using `0.12.5`

title: Type annotation check doesn't work for type aliases
body:
# Bug report

<!--
Hi, thanks for submitting a bug. We appreciate that.

But, we will need some information about what's wrong to help you.
-->

## What's wrong
Type annotation check doesn't work if type aliases are used. For example, this code
```
type_alias = Literal[None]

def my_func(arg: type_alias):
    pass
```
passes flake8 checks without raising `WPS701` error, while this code
```
def my_func(arg: Literal[None]):
    pass
```
makes flake8 complain: "WPS701 Found useless `Literal[None]` typing annotation".
## How is that should be
Type annotation errors should be raised whether type aliases are used or not.

## System information
wemake-python-styleguide: 0.12.5

title: Typos in Docstrings
body:
Probably not super important but there is a fair bit of typos accumulated in the docstrings of various violations. Here is all the typos and word misuses I gathered from *one* file:

(Misspelled words are *italicized*. Words that should be added
are __bolden__. Words that should be removed are ~~crossed out~~.)

### wemake_python_styleguide/violations/consistency.py

### Misspellings
* Line 426: Forbids *comparision* ...
* Line 494: Forbids *comparision* ...
* Line 1075: Forbids to use implicit string *contacatenation*
* Line 1312: ... that you *migth* have to ...
* Line 1413: ... to write long *stirngs* that does not ...
* Line 1513: ... hex, and *expanentional* numbers.
* Line 1661: ... throw *``ZeroDivisoionError``*
* Line 1667: Use *``ZeroDivisoionError``* ...
* Line 1688: ... math *opeartions*
* Line 1695: ... is also *redundunt*.
* Line 1698: ... zero *operaionts*.

### Wrong Grammer
* Line 467: should be written __in__ lowercase.
* Line 882: Use lowercase modifiers ~~should be written in lowercase~~.
* Line 1076: ... since you can ~~possible~~ __possibly__ miss a comma.
* Line 1514: There are ~ ~~infinitive~~ __infinite__ ways to ...
* Line 1520: ... numbers in ~~a~~ __an__ infinite ways?

### Less-than-ideal Grammer?
* Line 796: ... ~~when~~ __in case of__ a single ...
* Line 797: ... ~~when~~ __in case of__ a multi-line...
* Line 1145: ... might ~~be~~ also __be__ an overuse ...
* Line 1148: ... make sure it makes ~~any~~ sense.
* Line 1176: ... make sure it makes ~~any~~ sense.
* Line 1487: ... (we discourage ~~to use~~ __using__ them)
* Line 1574: Forbids __to__ use ~~lower-case~~ lowercase letters as ...
* Line 1581: Use ~~upper-case~~ uppercase  
* Line 1758: Forbids imports that ~~outside of the module~~ may cause confusion __outside of the module__.

Instead of fixing them piecemeal, I think it would be nice to just open an issue and let one guy get an easy PR, now being Hacktoberfest and all.

If nobody would take it, I can work on it.

title: Allow `super()` as overused expression
body:
We need to add a new predicate to allow `super()` calls here: https://github.com/wemake-services/wemake-python-styleguide/blob/39a3caeb9883c3112d878a88038e8b7331389265/wemake_python_styleguide/visitors/ast/complexity/overuses.py#L114

It is obviously allowed.

Then we need to add a unit test here: https://github.com/wemake-services/wemake-python-styleguide/blob/ed1afeb3366525f0b3f1adc346a189a3c0f3b923/tests/test_visitors/test_ast/test_complexity/test_overuses/test_overused_expressions.py

That's it. It is beginner friendly.

title: WPS440 Property false positive or missing solution
body:
# Bug report

## What's wrong

The following code will raise WPS440 even though it is the pythonic way (as far as I understand the documentation):

```
    @property
    def last_timestamp(self) -> int:
        """Return last timestamp a frame was pre processed."""
        return self._last_timestamp

    @last_timestamp.setter
    def last_timestamp(self, last_timestamp: int):
        """Set the last timestamp a frame was pre processed."""
        self._last_timestamp = last_timestamp
```

## How is that should be

It should either not raise WPS440 or there should be a solution on how to deal with properties or more specifically property setters/getters.

title: Underscore is forbidden as an alias for gettext

milestone.title: Version 0.14 aka python3.8
milestone.description:
`python3.8` will be released on `Monday, 2019-10-21`
https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0569/#schedule

We need to support it in two month.

body:
# Bug report
## What's wrong
The use of `_` as an alias for **gettext** is considered a violation of the rule [WPS121](https://wemake-python-stylegui.de/en/latest/pages/usage/violations/naming.html#wemake_python_styleguide.violations.naming.UnusedVariableIsUsedViolation).

```python
from django.utils.translation import gettext as _

output = _("Welcome to my site.")
```

> Found usage of a variable marked as unused: _ flake8(WPS121)

## How is that should be
`_` should be allowed as an alias for **gettext()** and **gettext_lazy()**, as this is conventional:

> This function is usually aliased as _()

https://docs.python.org/3/library/gettext.html#gettext.gettext

> It’s convention to import this as a shorter alias, _, to save typing.

https://docs.djangoproject.com/en/2.2/topics/i18n/translation/#standard-translation

title: Wrong and correct examples of nested annotations mixed up in docs for Union type
body:
# Bug report

<!--
Hi, thanks for submitting a bug. We appreciate that.

But, we will need some information about what's wrong to help you.
-->

## What's wrong

From ``NestedAnnotationsViolation`` class docstring:
```
Example::
        # Correct:
        Literal[1, 2, 3, "foo", 5, None]
        Union[Union[int, str], float]

        # Wrong:
        Literal[Literal[Literal[1, 2, 3], "foo"], 5, None]
        Union[int, str, float]
```
There is a mistake: correct and wrong examples for ``Union`` type are mixed up. If I run flake8 passing it a file which contains ``Union[int, str, float]`` annotation, no error will be raised. And for ``Union[Union[int, str], float]`` WPS702 is raised. Both are expected behaviour I guess, just a mismatch in documentation.
## How is that should be

```
Example::
        # Correct:
        Literal[1, 2, 3, "foo", 5, None]
        Union[int, str, float]

        # Wrong:
        Literal[Literal[Literal[1, 2, 3], "foo"], 5, None]
        Union[Union[int, str], float]
```
<!--

  Love wemake-python-styleguide? ❤️
  Do you want your bugs to be solved faster?

  Please consider supporting our collective:
👉  https://opencollective.com/wemake-python-styleguide/donate

-->

title: WPS317: handle tuples, lists,... in parameters

labels.name: duplicate
labels.description: This issue or pull request already exists

body:
Hello! I have a suggestion for this violation. For example, we have the code:
```python
demo_func(
    (1, 2),
    (1, 2),
    (1, 3),
)
```

And we have violation WPS317. I understand that "top-level" arguments should be placed vertically, but each argument is a tuple and it will be more beautiful to place members horizontally. Maybe this rule for each nested argument should be processed separately?

# Bug report

<!--
Hi, thanks for submitting a bug. We appreciate that.

But, we will need some information about what's wrong to help you.
-->

## What's wrong

We need to ensure that `I_CONTROL_CODE` setting is respected for the `BadMagicModuleFunctionViolation`. It happens here: https://github.com/wemake-services/wemake-python-styleguide/blob/master/wemake_python_styleguide/visitors/ast/modules.py#L88

Related #461 

## How is that should be

It should not raise this violation when `I_CONTROL_CODE` is set to false.
All we need to do is to check for `self.options.i_control_code` in this method.

title: `if` after `else` in `try` raises false positive WPS513
body:
# Bug report

<!--
Hi, thanks for submitting a bug. We appreciate that.

But, we will need some information about what's wrong to help you.
-->

## What's wrong

Code:

```python
        try:
            return_value = ast.literal_eval(node.body)
        except ValueError:
            # The value was not literal, it's ok.
            return
        else:
            if return_value in self._primitive_values:
                self.add_violation(ImplicitPrimitiveViolation(node))
```

Output:

```
329:13   WPS513 Found implicit `elif` condition
  if return_value in self._primitive_values:
```

<!-- Describe what is not working. Please, attach a traceback. -->

## How is that should be

It should not raise this violation. It is not a part of `if` / `else` case.

title: False positive `WPS417 Found non-unique item in hash: None`

title: Split the rule that checks using `*()`, `*[]` and `**{}` in calls into different rules

milestone.title: Version 0.12.x
milestone.description: These are fixes for the `0.12.x` series.

body:
# Rule request

<!-- Thanks for coming up with a proposal! -->

## Thesis

Divide the [WPS517](https://github.com/wemake-services/wemake-python-styleguide/blob/9105869ee4d38775ffbf4348ef29492794c1177f/wemake_python_styleguide/violations/refactoring.py#L704) rule into different rules, which individually check `*()` /  `*[]` and `**{}` expressions.

Related issue: https://github.com/wemake-services/wemake-python-styleguide/issues/715

## Reasoning

`**{}` can be used when the variable contains the name of the parameter, which should be passed to some method.  

For example:

```python
def user_by_username(username: str):
    return User.objects.get(**{User.USERNAME_FIELD: username})
```

To satisfy the linter, the code can be rewritten like this:

```python
def user_by_username(username: str):
    kwargs = {User.USERNAME_FIELD: username}
    return User.objects.get(**kwargs)
```

But I think it would be better if I could disable the linter check specifically for the `**{}` expression.

title: Change how we define `__slots__`

milestone.title: Version 0.12.0
milestone.description: This release will contain a lot of new rules.

body:
# Bug report

<!--
Hi, thanks for submitting a bug. We appreciate that.

But, we will need some information about what's wrong to help you.
-->

## What's wrong

I have made a mistake when decided to use tuples for slots (#379). That's more performant but semantically incorrect. 

Now when we rework how `__slots__` are defined in #696 I guess it is a pretty good idea to:
1. Enforce `set` for `__slots__`
2. Drop unique check for tuple elements in `__slots__`, since we already check all sets to be correct

title: Change how "return" in "finally" works

milestone.title: Version 0.12.0
milestone.description: This release will contain a lot of new rules.

body:
I am pretty sure that currently we are doing it wrong: we check that both `try` and `finally` return something.

Things to checks:
1. That any `break`, `raise` ?, and `return` in finally is restricted 
2. `try` and `else` cannot both have `return`, `break`, `raise` ? statements

Sorry for the bad description, it is more like a research task.

Related: http://pylint.pycqa.org/en/latest/technical_reference/features.html see `lost-exception`

title: Z331 raised twice
body:
# Bug report

<!--
Hi, thanks for submitting a bug. We appreciate that.

But, we will need some information about what's wrong to help you.
-->

## What's wrong

This code:

```python
def report_progress(function):
    """Decorates a function to print its execution status."""
    @wraps(function)
    def decorator(*args, **kwargs):
        try:
            function_result = function(*args, **kwargs)
            message = '{0} succeed'.format(function.__name__)
            print(colored(message, 'green'))  # noqa: T001
            return function_result
        except Exception as exc:
            message = '{0} failed due to exception: {1}'.format(
                function.__name__, exc,
            )

            print(colored(message, 'red'))  # noqa: T001
            raise

    return decorator
```

Raises two violations:

```
./kira_setup/logging.py:16:13: Z331 Found local variable that are only used in `return` statements
./kira_setup/logging.py:16:13: Z331 Found local variable that are only used in `return` statements
```

I am using `0.10`

title: Do not count type annotations as strings

# Bug report

Hi, thanks for submitting a bug. We appreciate that.

But, we will need some information about what's wrong to help you.
-->

## What's wrong

When running 0.10 over https://github.com/dry-python/returns I get:

```
returns/result.py:0:1: Z226 Found string constant over-use: Result[_NewValueType, _NewErrorType]
returns/maybe.py:0:1: Z226 Found string constant over-use: Maybe[_NewValueType]
```

Which is not correct. Because these are types, not strings.
It would be incorrect to use them as constants.

def foreign_jwt_authentication(token: bytes):  # noqa: Z331

body:
# Bug report

<!--
Hi, thanks for submitting a bug. We appreciate that.

But, we will need some information about what's wrong to help you.
-->

## What's wrong

```python
breakpoint()
```

This code should not pass.
We must check if any of the plugins do check for it.
Otherwise, we can add it to forbidden builtins calls.

PEP: https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0553/

False positive for `./returns/maybe.pyi:79:5: Z459 Found complex default value`

```python
@final
class _Nothing(Maybe[Any]):
    _inner_value: None

    def __init__(self, inner_value: None = ...) -> None:
        ...
```

title: There is no possible way to write multiline byte string.
body:
# Bug report

Consider we have this code snippet:

```python
@pytest.fixture
def jpeg_image():
   """The smallest possible JPEG image.jpg file."""
   return (
       b'\xff\xd8\xff\xdb\x00C\x00\x03\x02\x02\x02\x02\x02\x03\x02\x02\x02'
       b'\x03\x03\x03\x03\x04\x06\x04\x04\x04\x04\x04\x08\x06\x06\x05\x06'
       b'\t\x08\n\n\t\x08\t\t\n\x0c\x0f\x0c\n\x0b\x0e\x0b\t\t\r\x11\r\x0e'
       b'\x0f\x10\x10\x11\x10\n\x0c\x12\x13\x12\x10\x13\x0f\x10\x10\x10\xff'
       b'\xc9\x00\x0b\x08\x00\x01\x00\x01\x01\x01\x11\x00\xff\xcc\x00\x06'
       b'\x00\x10\x10\x05\xff\xda\x00\x08\x01\x01\x00\x00?\x00\xd2\xcf '
       b'\xff\xd9'
   )
```

## What's wrong

There is no possible way to format code example above to make all linter rules pass.

title: Z118 false positive on long attributes
body:
# Bug report

## What's wrong

```python
# -*- coding: utf-8 -*-

from gitlab.v4.objects import Project

def configure(project: Project) -> None:
    project.only_allow_merge_if_all_discussions_are_resolved = True
```

This code raises a false positive violation:

```
kira_setup/pipelines/project.py:27:5: Z118 Found too long name: only_allow_merge_if_all_discussions_are_resolved
```

## How is that should be

We should only check attributes for `self`, because other attributes might be a part of foreign API. That we cannot change.

title: False positive for Z121 when using `_` for unused var names
body:
# Bug report

## What's wrong

This code triggers `Z121`:

```python
def logo_and_user():
    user, _ = User.objects.get_or_create(username='sobolevn')
    logo, _ = Logo.objects.get_or_create(username='sobolevn')  # here
```

Log: `test.py:4:11: Z121 Found usage of a variable marked as unused: _`
But it should not, since these variables are unused.

## How is that should be

It should not raise any `Z121` violations here.

## System information

I am using `8.0.1`

# Bug report

<!--
Hi, thanks for submitting a bug. We appreciate that.

But, we will need some information about what's wrong to help you.
-->

## What's wrong

```python
def test(office, returned_item):
    assert returned_item['id'] == office.id
```

raises `Z309 Found reversed comparison order` violation

## How is that should be

It should not raise a violation. We use variables on both sides.

## System information

I am using `0.8.1` release.

title: "Z456 Found incorrect `super()` call: not inside method" reported incorrectly
body:
# Bug report

<!--
Hi, thanks for submitting a bug. We appreciate that.

But, we will need some information about what's wrong to help you.
-->

## What's wrong
`Z456  Found incorrect `super()` call: not inside method` is reported when ANY function/class in the same file has nested functions / class definitions (super weird)
```
class Test:
    def __init__(self):
        super().__init__()


def another():
    def func():
        return 1

    return func
```
```
flake8 main.py
main.py:3:9: Z456 Found incorrect `super()` call: not inside method
1     Z456 Found incorrect `super()` call: not inside method
```

I would be glad to disable it, but unfortunately, another useful violation has the same code ("Z456 Found incorrect `super()` call: remove arguments").
For some reason `wps_context` of `_ast.Call` node (super() call) is `_ast.FunctionDef` on line №7 (`def func()`).

## How is that should be
Z456 should not be reported

title: "pyflakes" failed during execution due to "'ExceptHandler' object has no attribute 'depth'"

labels.name: dependencies
labels.description: Pull requests that update a dependency file

body:
# Bug report

<!--
Hi, thanks for submitting a bug. We appreciate that.

But, we will need some information about what's wrong to help you.
-->

## What's wrong
`flake8` fails to run `pyflakes` when `flake-bandit` version is >=2.0.0
changing `flake-bandit` version to 1.0.2 fixes the error.
Similar error was reported earlier https://github.com/wemake-services/wemake-python-styleguide/issues/112
<!-- Describe what is not working. Please, attach a traceback. -->
main.py

```
def test():
    try:
        x = 5
        if True:
            x = 10
    except AttributeError:
        pass

```
There should be `if` inside `try` block with at least one `except` clause.
The variable shoud be defined inside `try` and reassigned inside `if`.
Also using bare `except` removes the error.

```
flake8 main.py
"pyflakes" failed during execution due to "'ExceptHandler' object has no attribute 'depth'"
Run flake8 with greater verbosity to see more details
```

`pyflakes` breaks [here](https://github.com/PyCQA/pyflakes/blob/6501af45203dfa3e2d422cfb3ebbecff853db47f/pyflakes/checker.py#L827) when for some reason
`rnode` has attrbute `parent` but doesn't have `depth`.
## How is that should be

<!-- Describe how it should work. -->
It should not raise any errors.

title: Variable annotation complexity is not checked

labels.name: dependencies
labels.description: Pull requests that update a dependency file

body:
# Bug report

<!--
Hi, thanks for submitting a bug. We appreciate that.

But, we will need some information about what's wrong to help you.
-->

## What's wrong

Variables like:

```python
some_value: List[Union[List[str], Dict[str, Dict[str, str]]]] = ...
```

are ignored by `flake8-annotations-complexity` it only checks functions for now.
Original issue: https://github.com/best-doctor/flake8-annotations-complexity/issues/1
Related: #449 

## How is that should be

It should check variables as well.

## System information

We are using `0.0.1` at the moment.

title: Describe reasoning for each individual keyword we disallow
body:
Users report that it is not clear why `del`, `pass`, and other keyword are not allowed.
I need to clarify it.

title: Add links to the source code of projects that use coding comment
body:
Users sometimes ask me why coding-comment is required. 
And providing a documentation about the consequences of not having them is required to solve users's questions.

# Rule request

<!-- Thanks for coming up with a proposal! -->

## Thesis

Allow to use `# type: some_type` in loop statements

## Reasoning

In some cases the editor cannot detect the object type.

```python
    async def iter_channel_dialogs(self) -> AsyncIterator[Dialog]:
        """Iterate through public channels."""
        async for dialog in self.iter_dialogs():  # type: Dialog
            if dialog.is_channel and dialog.entity.username:
                yield dialog
```

body:
# Bug report

## What's wrong

This code raises `Z454 Found incorrect base class` violation.

```python
from typing import Generic, TypeVar


HandlesType = TypeVar('T')

class Base(Generic[HandlesType]):
    def process(self, pipeline: HandlesType):
        return pipeline
```

## How is that should be

It should work fine. Generic classes with `[]` are widely used.

## System information

I am using `0.7.0`.

title: AttributeError: 'NoneType' object has no attribute 'lineno'
False positive Z114 for time-based suffixes
body:
# Bug report

## What's wrong

The Z114 rule restricts numbers in variables, unless they are trailing ones. However, there are some cases when this rule is wrong:

```
Z114 Found underscored name pattern: clicks_1h
Z114 Found underscored name pattern: shows_1h
Z114 Found underscored name pattern: shows_24h
Z114 Found underscored name pattern: clicks_24h
```

We have a code., which calculates some CTR metrics for 1 hour and 24 hour period. Obliviously for us is to include the period in variable name to avoid any confusions. But this makes such names illegal for linter.

## How is that should be

This rule should allow to have time-based suffixes.

title: Incorrect line number for `Z110`
body:
# Bug report

<!--
Hi, thanks for submitting a bug. We appreciate that.

But, we will need some information about what's wrong to help you.
-->

## What's wrong

Consider this example:

```python
    @classmethod  # lineno: 95
    def from_token(
        cls: Type[TAssign],
        token: lex.LexToken,
        equal: lex.LexToken = None,
        value: lex.LexToken = None,
    ) -> TAssign:
```

Report: `dotenv_linter/grammar/fst.py:95:5: Z110 Found wrong variable name: value`

## How is that should be

It should report `value: lex.LexToken = None,` as an incorrect line.

xy = [1
]

title: Async for loops are not checked for `RedundantLoopElseViolation` and `LambdaInsideLoopViolation`
body:
# Bug report

## What's wrong

This code:

```python
async def wrapper():
     async for user in get_users():
           print(user, lambda: True)
     else:
           print('done!')
```

does not rise both `RedundantLoopElseViolation` and `LambdaInsideLoopViolation`. 
This happens  because `WrongLoopVisitor` does not work with `AsyncFor`.

## How is that should be

`AsyncFor` should be checked the same way as regular `For` node.

title: Some statements are not checked for too big offset
body:
# Bug report

## What's wrong

```python
if True:
    print(True)
```

This code will not raise a violation when setting `_max_offset_blocks` to `0`.
Because `Call` node are not checked.

## How is that should be

It should raise a `TooDeepNestingViolation`.

title: `staticmethod`s are not treated as class members, instead they are treated as module members
body:
# Bug report

<!--
Hi, thanks for submitting a bug. We appreciate that.

But, we will need some information about what's wrong to help you.
-->

## What's wrong

```python
class Test(object):
     @staticmethod
     def method(): ...
```

This code will raise a warning with `--max-module-members` set to `1`.
But, it should not.

## How is that should be

It should not raise a module level warning.
`@staticmethod` should be treated as a class member.

But, we will need some information about what's wrong to help you.
-->

`MONGO_PORT = 27017  # defalut mongo port`

title: Incorrect parameters count for `async` methods

labels.name: dependencies
labels.description: Pull requests that update a dependency file

body:
# Bug report

## What's wrong

`async` method like this:

```python
class Some(object):
      async def run(self, param): ...
```

will result in two arguments.
This happens since `function_type` from `pep8-naming` package works incorrectly.
Related issue: https://github.com/PyCQA/pep8-naming/issues/80

## How is that should be

It should count only one argument: `param`. And set `function_type` to `method`.

## System information

Affected version:

```
[[package]]
category = "main"
description = "Check PEP-8 naming conventions, plugin for flake8"
name = "pep8-naming"
optional = false
python-versions = "*"
version = "0.7.0"
```

title: Bug: protected attributes should be permitted with `super()` call
body:
# Bug report

<!--
Hi, thanks for submitting a bug. We appreciate that.

But, we will need some information about what's wrong to help you.
-->

## What's wrong

Currently it is impossible to do something as the following:

```python
class Some(object):
      def __init__(self):
          super()._catch()
```

This will introduce a warning that should not be introduced. 


## How is that should be

We should check that 
1. `super()` is allowed
2. magic method are allowed
3. private names are ignored from this check

title: async def offset is broken in ast for versions below 3.7rc2
body:
# Bug report
Python with versions below 3.7rc2 are counting offset for async def functions wrong, needs to work around this, so in case of this OffsetVisitor is working completely wrong. 
<!--
Hi, thanks for submitting a bug. We appreciate that.

But, we will need some information about what's wrong to help you.
-->

## What's wrong
Offset for async functions is calculated wrong due to [bug](https://bugs.python.org/issue29205) in python versions <3.7rc2. 
```python
assert_errors = <function assert_errors.<locals>.factory at 0x051D4810>
parse_ast_tree = <function parse_ast_tree.<locals>.factory at 0x051D48E8>
code = "\nasync def container():\n    async with open('some') as temp:\n        pass\n"
number_of_errors = 1
options = <function options.<locals>.factory at 0x05251390>

    def factory(visitor: BaseVisitor, errors: Sequence[str]):
>       assert len(errors) == len(visitor.violations)
E       AssertionError: assert 1 == 2
E        +  where 1 = len([<class 'wemake_python_styleguide.violations.complexity.TooDeepNestingViolation'>])
E        +  and   2 = len([<wemake_python_styleguide.violations.complexity.TooDeepNestingViolation object at 0x058C4B10>, <wemake_python_styleguide.violations.complexity.TooDeepNestingViolation object at 0x058C4690>])
E        +    where [<wemake_python_styleguide.violations.complexity.TooDeepNestingViolation object at 0x058C4B10>, <wemake_python_styleguide.violations.complexity.TooDeepNestingViolation object at 0x058C4690>] = <wemake_python_styleguide.visitors.ast.complexity.offset.OffsetVisitor object at 0x0589CA10>.violations
```
Also, testing it in python shell:
```python
>>> f = ast.parse(nested_asyncwith)
>>> f.body[0].col_offset
6
>>> f.body[0]
<_ast.AsyncFunctionDef object at 0x7fe41dbf0e10>
``` 
where
```python
nested_asyncwith = """
async def container():
    async with open('some') as temp:
        pass
"""
```

<!-- Describe what is not working. Please, attach a traceback. -->

## How is that should be
We should fix the async def offset calculations.

title: Magic number is found even though it was assigned to a variable

price_in_euro = 3.33  # could be changed later
total = get_items_from_cart() * price_in_euro

foo = 19091

title: Variables inside list comprehensions are treated as locals.
body:
# Bug report

<!--
Hi, thanks for submitting a bug. We appreciate that.

But, we will need some information about what's wrong to help you.
-->

## What's wrong

When rule about restricting the number of local variables is applied to function code it makes an error
of counting variables inside list comprehensions towards the total number of local variables. It then triggers `TooManyLocalsViolation`, which is, in that case, may seem unneeded.

Example:

```python
def func():
      a = 1
      l = [
          n * i  
          for n in range(42) 
          for i in range(n)
      ]

```

There are only 2 local variables here, but code will count 4.

## How is that should be

Variables inside comprehensions (both list and dictionary, possibly including generators) should not count toward the total number of local variables.

## System information

### flake8 information

Contents of `flake8 --bug-report`:

title: flake-isort generating false warnings when running flake8 on Windows

labels.name: dependencies
labels.description: Pull requests that update a dependency file

body:
# Bug report

`flake-isort` is generating false warnings when running `flake8` with `flake8-isort` installed on Windows 10 machine.

## What's wrong

Having file with the contents:

```python
# -*- coding: UTF-8 -*-
"""Module docstring."""

print('hello')
```

Running

```bash
C:\Temp\SampleEnvIsortOnly\Scripts
(SampleEnvIsortOnly) λ flake8 "C:\Development\Flake8PluginDev\foo.py"
```

on Windows 10 gives

```
C:\Development\Flake8PluginDev\foo.py:2:1: I001 isort found an import in the wrong position
C:\Development\Flake8PluginDev\foo.py:4:1: I003 isort expected 1 blank line in imports, found 0
```

when there are really no imports in the file.

Running 

```bash
(SamplePyEnv) linuxuser@LinuxMachine:~/Development/SamplePyEnv$ flake8 /home/linuxuser/Development/Sample/foo.py
```

on the file with the same contents on Linux Ubuntu does not produce any warnings.

## How is that should be

The `flake8-isort` should not generate these false warnings for file with the provided content on Windows machines.

## System information

### flake8 information

Contents of `flake8 --bug-report`:

```
(SampleEnvIsortOnly) λ flake8 --bug-report
{

    {
      "dependency": "setuptools",

title: Stricter `None` checks
body:
There are places in the code like this:

```python
    def check_nested_import(self, node: AnyImport) -> None:
        text = get_error_text(node)
        parent = getattr(node, 'parent', None)
        if not isinstance(parent, ast.Module):
            self.delegate.add_error(NestedImportViolation(node, text=text))
```

And there's an issue there! If `parent` is `None` - the check fails.
We need to go through the code to find these kind of issues.

title: Version 0.0.8 is unusable: missing `typing_extensions`
body:
We have missed `typing_extensions`. It is a dev-only requirement.

```
ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'typing_extensions'
manager.py                 185 CRITICAL Flake8 failed to load plugin "Z" due to No module named 'typing_extensions'.
```

If you want to still use this version run `pip install typing_extensions`.

title: Refactor how options are defined
body:
Currently we have almost 10 different options.
It is not possible to use just plain registration logic any more.

We need to refactor it somehow.

title: Reduce the number of `getattr` calls
body:
There are a lot of places in the code where we use `getattr` to access different properties of the node.

We need to reduce this number, removing the unused checks.

title: Do we really need all `.generic_visit` calls?
body:
Some `self.generic_visit` calls are not required.
They are even decreasing performance.

title: Errors are not tested
body: After I have moved errors to a package, tests do not check codes' uniqueness and other checks.

title: Change how `MAX_` value are treated
body:
Currently we raise exception when reaching `max` value in complexity checks.
But, it is uncommon to do so. Let's change it to be `max + 1`.
Where `max` is still allowed.

title: Local variables count does not work correctly
body:
Currently we have a broken logic that calculates local variables count:

```python
def _check_arguments_count(self, node: ast.FunctionDef):
        counter = 0
        has_extra_self_or_cls = 0
        max_arguments_count = self.options.max_arguments
        if self._is_method(getattr(node, 'function_type', None)):
            has_extra_self_or_cls = 1

        counter += len(node.args.args)
        counter += len(node.args.kwonlyargs)

        if node.args.vararg:
            counter += 1

        if node.args.kwarg:
            counter += 1

        if counter > max_arguments_count + has_extra_self_or_cls:
            self.add_error(
                TooManyArgumentsViolation(node, text=node.name),
            )
```

It report to have more that `5` local variables. 
> .../wemake-python-styleguide/wemake_python_styleguide/visitors/high_complexity.py:48:5: Z202 Found too many local variables "_check_arguments_count"

When we have only:
- `counter`
- ` has_extra_self_or_cls`
- `max_arguments_count`

It happens due to these lines:

```python
def _update_variables(self, function: ast.FunctionDef):
        max_local_variables_count = self.options.max_local_variables
        self.variables[function.name] += 1
        if self.variables[function.name] == max_local_variables_count:
            self.add_error(
                TooManyLocalsViolation(function, text=function.name),
            )
```

What happens here is:
1. we do not track what variables were already assigned
2. we do not track if variables are just redefined 

This needs to be fixed.

title: Version 0.0.2 can't be used with pip
body:
In some cases on line
```
node_parent = getattr(node, 'parent')
```
of `WrongModuleMetadataVisitor` we get
```
AttributeError: 'Assign' object has no attribute 'parent'
```

The bug can be fixed by the correct usage of `getattr`: 
```
node_parent = getattr(node, 'parent', None)
```

The PR with the fix and a regression test will be ready in a day.
